facts.text: In certain assessment proceedings under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the assessee was charged with interest under sub-sec. 8 of s. 18A.
The assessee company had not been assessed before, so sub-sec. 3 of s. 18A applied, requiring it to make its own estimate of advance tax payable and pay accordingly.
The assessee neither submitted any estimate nor paid any tax in advance.
There are three orders charging interest under s.18A(8), one for each of three assessment years.
Assessee's contention rejected by Appellate Commissioner but accepted by Appellate Tribunal.
Respondent Commissioner obtained reference to Punjab High Court on the question of construction of s.18A sub-secs 6,8,9.
High Court answered the question against the assessee.
Payment of advance tax under s.18A to be made on June 15, September 15, December 15, and March 15 in each financial year.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on a true construction of sub-Sections 6, 8 and 9 of Section 18A of the Indian Income-tax Act, the interest referred to in sub-Section 8 is chargeable for failure on the part of an assessee to submit an estimate of his income and pay tax, as required by the terms of sub-Section 3 of that Section.

petitioner_arguments.text: Since no tax was paid at all, it is not possible to calculate interest in the manner laid down in sub-sec. 6, as there is no 'first day of January in the financial year in which the tax was paid' from which calculation commences, and no shortfall between 80% of assessed tax and amount paid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Literal construction of sub-secs. 6 and 8 of s.18A; rule from Cape Brandy Syndicate v. Inland Revenue Commission

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-sec. 8 has no operation in a case where no tax paid, so assessee cannot be charged interest.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Taxing statutes to be construed strictly: 'In a taxing Act one has to look merely at what is clearly said. There is no room for any intendment.'

respondent_arguments.text: Interest under sub-sec. 8 is chargeable even for failure to submit estimate and pay tax under sub-sec. 3.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sub-secs. 6 and 8 are machinery provisions for calculating interest liability clearly imposed by sub-sec. 8; construe to make machinery workable (utres valeat potius quam pereat)

court_reasoning.text: Sub-sec. 8 clearly imposes liability for interest where no payment of tax made in accordance with s.18A; sub-sec. 6 lays down machinery for its calculation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions dealing with machinery for assessment to be construed to make charge effective, not strictly as charging provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Read sub-sec. 6 as applying 'from the 1st day of January in the financial year in which the tax ought to have been paid'; shortfall is entire 80% where nothing paid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: This makes provision workable without defeating intent of sub-sec. 8; those who underpay and those who don't pay at all put in same position.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-sec. 9 for penalty does not affect construction of sub-secs. 6 and 8; interest is not penalty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Penalty under s.28 via sub-sec.9 is additional and for different reasons.

holdings.text: Interest under s.18A(8) is chargeable for failure to submit estimate and pay advance tax under s.18A(3), calculated per machinery in s.18A(6) adapted for non-payment cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cape Brandy Syndicate v. Inland Revenue Commission
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule of strict construction for taxing provisions: look merely at what is clearly said.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: No tax if not covered within four corners of taxing statute; no inference or analogy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mahaliram Ramjidas
precedents_cited.relevance: Machinery provisions in taxing statutes to be construed to make workable (utres valeat potius quam pereat).

precedents_cited.case_name: India United Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Machinery sections to effectuate charging sections.

precedents_cited.case_name: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Once liability fixed, statute designed to be workable; interpretation to secure that object.
Rules for assessment and collection to be interpreted largely to effectuate liability.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Advance payment of tax; liability and calculation of interest for underpayment or non-payment; penalty provisions.

outcome.summary: The appeals are dismissed and the decision of the High Court answering the question in favour of the Revenue is upheld.

key_quotes.text: "In a taxing Act one has to look merely at what is clearly said. There is no room for any intendment. There is no equity about a tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites strict construction rule but distinguishes as not applying to machinery provisions.

key_quotes.text: Sub-section 8 intended to and did in the clearest term impose a charge for interest... this provision only lays down the machinery for assessing the amount of interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding: separates charging provision from machinery.

key_quotes.text: We, therefore, think that we should read sub-sec. 6... in a manner which makes it workable and thereby prevent the clear intention of sub-sec. 8 being defeated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purposive construction for machinery to effectuate liability.
